Department of State Monrovia, October3, 1864

Sir, In consequence of- certain dangers with- which this Republic is suddenly threatened by the recent stranding of our only naval vessel and quard costa, the "Quail" and the probablity of our coast beignm, for a- long time, in an exposed and defenceless conditions
Hon. W.H. Seward Secretary of State Washington D.C.

I am directed by the- President to make- application through you to the government of the United States for a small revenue- cutter or gun-boat for which this Republic will stipulate to pay- after a turn of years to- be agreed upon by the Chargè d'Affaires of Liberia in the United- States, and whomsoever the United States- government may appoint as its agents to negotiate on its behalf Among

Among the dangers to be- apprehended are, 1st the- invasion of our feeble- settlements on the coast- at a distance from the capital by predatory tribes who taking advantage of the emergency the- absence of a suitable- vessel to throw forces- readily among them- would seek the slightest pretext for plundering the settlements.
Owing ton the influence destructive of the slave- trade, which this- Republic has exercised, not

not a few of the older- aborigines who formerly- enriched themselves by- the nefarious traffic entertain bitter and resentful feelings against Liberia, which, whenever there is the least opportunity, they never fail to- manifest. The younger natives, I am happy to- perceive the superior- advantages of lawful commerce over the slave- trade, and we may hope that are long not only the overt practice but every feeling favorable to-
to it will be completely annihilated within our- borders.

2 From what I have- just said, it may be- readily inferred that- another danger to the- Republic likely to result from the absence of a- guarda costa would be the revival of the slave- trade in isolated- localities. Those sections of country would again be the scene of the- horrible barbarities and cruelties of former years, and a deplorable check would
would be imposed- upon the growing- agriculture and- commerce of the country.

3 The third and last- danger, which I shall mention, to be apprehended by us from the naval- deficiency in question would be the constant- infraction of our- revenue laws by certain European traders;- especially as there will likely go into operation on the 1st of January- 1865, our new law- confirming all foreign vessels to the legally- constituted "ports of entry" Many

Many of the European- traders seem opposed to- this law, not because it is not just and equitable, but because they think- that their traffic hereafter- will not be so lucrative as it has been; and, through their influence, by- clandestine visits to- native tribes on the coast; they would be able to excite and aid them to acts of hostility against the- governments.
The government of- Liberia has never before felt at liberty to make application, in emergencies,

to the government of the- United States. BUt such has been the vivid and- courteous treatment of- the present governments Liberia, that we feel- emboldened to take this step-assured that we- have your ardent- sympathy in our efforts to build up andmaintain an independent- Afric-American- nationality on this- continent.
The President and people of Liberia have observed with emotions of sincere pleasure the- enlightened patriotism and

and exalted philanthropy which, since the breaking out of the unhappy context, have influenced the councils of the American nation. Among the decisions of- that govenrments which- Liberia and every negro- community must hail with the most unfounded applause, are first, the- decision that slavery shall not hence forth be extended under the American flag over territories now free;- secondly, that the African slave trade shall never be revivied or renewed; thirdly, that slavery shall be- forever abolished within the federal District of Columbia fourthly
fourthly, that slaves- escaping or captured- from disloyal masters- shall not be restored to- slavery but shall be free.

These and numerous other equally liberal acts fortify us in the belief that the- United States government will not fail to accord us any assistance in its- power in view of the imminent emergencies to which I have referred.
In closing this- communication, I beg to- express the hop ethat the lamentable civil war now distracting your lately prosperous and happy country, may be brought

brought to a speedy- termination, consisting- with the honor and dignity- of the United tates, conducive- to the welfare and happiness of all the inhabitants of that- great country, and promotive of the cause of civil liberty throughout the world.
I have the honor to be, with the highset consideration, Sir, your most obedient- humble servant Edward M. Blyden
